column1: Rhovanion or Wilderland was a large region of northern Middle-earth. The Great River Anduin flowed through it
column2: and the immense forest of Mirkwood was a part of it.

column1: Properly speaking Rhovanion was the name of a small region east of Greenwood
column2: which later was the Kingdom of Rhovanion
column3: but the name was used for all of Wilderland by the late Third Age.

column1: Many wild horses and wild kine roamed the plains of Rhovanion.
==History==
=== First Age ===
In the First Age the Elves passed through it during the Great Journey
column2: and much later the Atanatári (Fathers of Men) followed them. It is not otherwise mentioned until the Second Age.

column1: === Second Age ===
Rhovanion played host to two Silvan Elves Elf kingdoms ruled by Sindarin lords: Northern Greenwood and Lórinand (or Lothlórien).
The great battlefield (or Dagorlad) of the War of the Last Alliance against the host of Sauron lay in the south of Rhovanion
column2: and in the Gladden Fields of the Great River the High King of Gondor and Arnor

column1: === Third Age ===
In the early Third Age
column2: it was a quite populated area: in the north lay the Dwarves kingdoms of Lonely Mountain and the Dwarf halls in the Ered Mithrin
column3: and the Mannish kingdom of Dale
column4: in the north of the Great River Anduin lay the Mannish realm of Éothéod
column5: and in and around the south and east of Greenwood the Great lived the Men of Rhovanion.

column1: In  Rómendacil II of Gondor destroyed all camps of the Easterlings even beyond the Sea of Rhûn
column2: and a strong alliance with Rhovanion was forged. The King of Rhovanion at this time was Vidugavia
column3: and Prince Valacar of Gondor served in his army. Vidugavias daughter Vidumavi married Valacar
column4: and their son Vinitharya became King Eldacar (King of Gondor) in
column5: which led to the Kin-strife in . Eldacar fled to Rhovanion
column6: and with a Rhovanion army he reclaimed his Kingdom in .

column1: In the north of Greenwood lived the Silvan elves ruled by Thranduil
column2: and in the south of Greenwood and across the river in Lórinand ruled Amdír and later Amroth. In the far south
column3: near the great falls of Sarn Gebir
column4: watched the northern guard of Gondor
column5: and in the valleys of the Anduin lived Stoors (Hobbitss).

column1: In  the Great Plague devastated Rhovanion
column2: killing more than half its people. This left Rhovanion weakened
column3: and in  the Wainriders overran and enslaved Rhovanion. For 43 years Rhovanion was enslaved
column5: while Gondor attacked the Wainriders from the west. Rhovanion was freed
column6: but left extremely weakened. Many Men of Rhovanion left for Gondor
column7: where they were welcomed as distant relatives.

column1: In circa  Sauron returned as the Necromancer he took residence at Dol Guldur in the south of Greenwood. And Greenwood became evil
column2: and was renamed Mirkwood. The Dwarves of Erebor and the Men of Dale were destroyed and scattered when the Dragons Smaug took Erebor
column3: and Gondor retreated from the Falls. Some Men still lived along the forest
column4: notably the Beornings and the Men of Lake-town upon the Long Lake. The Men of Éothéod removed south at the invite of Gondor
column5: and settled the plains of Calenardhon
column6: later Rohan. After being driven out of Erebor the Dwarves relocated
column7: some went to the Iron Hills
column8: but most went to the Ered Luin in Eriador.

column1: At the end of the Third Age
column2: the Kingdoms of Erebor and Dale were restored as a result of the death of Smaug and the Battle of Five Armies
column3: and Sauron was removed from Mirkwood by the wizard Gandalf. During the War of the Ring it held off an invasion by Saurons forces
column4: and after Sauron was defeated Mirkwood was clean again
column6: or "Wood of Greenleaves". Some time during the Fourth Age Gondor claimed large parts of it.

column1: ==Boundaries==
*To the east: the River Running and the inland Sea of Rhûn.
*To the north: the Grey Mountains and Iron Hills
*To the west: the range of the Misty Mountains
*To the south: the line marked by the Limlight river
Important rivers were the Anduin or Great River
Major features were the forest of Mirkwood
column2: and the Long Lake of Lake-town.

column1: ==Etymology==
Rhovanion is Sindarin
Wilderland was a Hobbitish name.
column2: p. 14 J.R.R. Tolkien made Wilderland based on wilderness but with a side-reference to the verbs wilder
